description: The Islamic State (IS) also known as the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS) and The Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) is a Salafi militant organization whose goal is the establishment and expansion of a caliphate. IS has its origins in the early 2000s, when Abu Musab al-Zarqawi began training extremist militants. Zarqawis militants became a major participant in the Iraqi insurgency during the American occupation, first under the name Jamaat al-Tawhid waal-Jihad and then, after swearing fealty to Al Qaeda, as Al Qaeda in Iraq. Facing backlash from the community and increased security from U.S. and Iraqi forces, the group faced decline until 2011, when it began to grow through its involvement in the Syrian Civil War. In 2013, it changed its name to the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS). Over the course of 2013 and 2014, it quickly took over territory in Syria and Iraq. In addition to its rapid expansion, ISIS has also drawn attention for its public beheadings of Western captives and its large contingent of foreign fighters. On the ground, IS has fought Syrian government forces, Syrian rebel groups, the Iraqi military and militias, and the Kurdish peshmerga. The U.S. began airstrikes against the group in fall 2014.

description: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) is a Sunni terrorist organization and Al Qaeda affiliate based in Yemen, a country whose geography and tribal social structure are often said to provide an environment friendly to terrorist and militant groups. It was created in 2009 from the merger of the Yemeni and Saudi Arabian branches of Al Qaeda. AQAP has claimed numerous attacks in the country but also targets Westerners abroad. The group is best known internationally for the underwear bomber who attempted to detonate a bomb on a Detroit-bound airplane in 2009, and for the 2015 Charlie Hebdo attacks in Paris, for which it claimed responsibility. In 2014, it created an offshoot organization called Ansar al-Sharia in Yemen in order to rebrand the AQ name in the country and attract more followers. In 2015, AQAP used the turmoil of the conflict in Yemen to seize territory in the southeast.

description: The Mahdi Army, also known as the Jaysh al-Mahdi (JAM), is a Shiite militia led by Muqtada al-Sadr. The group was founded in 2003 and was considered one of the most dangerous groups in Iraq until early 2008. In March 2008, the Iraqi Security Forces and coalition troops launched a major offensive against the Mahdi Army in Basra, significantly undermining its capacity. After signing a ceasefire agreement with the coalition forces in 2008, Sadr reoriented the Mahdi Army to focus on social services provision for the Shiite community. In 2010, Sadr again redirected the focus of many members of the Mahdi army, this time to the upcoming parliamentary elections, before stepping out of the public eye in 2013. Then in June 2014, he reemerged to revive the Mahdi Army, now called the Peace Brigades, in order to join the fight against the Islamic State.

The group seeks to control territory within Somalia in order to establish a society based on its rigid interpretation of Shariah law. Although based in Somalia, Al Shabaab also conducts attacks in neighboring countries, such as Kenya. Al Shabaab emerged as an independent organization around December 2006 after breaking away from the Islamic Courts Union (ICU), for which it had served as the military wing. The organization is closely linked to Al Qaeda, and is also associated with the Afghan Taliban. However, unlike the Afghan Taliban, which focuses on combatting U.S.-led coalition forces in Afghanistan, the TTP focuses on combatting Pakistani security forces. The TTP is based in South Waziristan and has three central goals: to enforce Shariah law in Pakistan; to establish a unified front to combat U.S.-led coalition forces in Afghanistan; and to conduct defensive jihad against Pakistani security forces. Ultimately, the group also seeks to overthrow the Pakistani government and establish an Islamic caliphate in Pakistan. Since 2014, internal splits and Pakistani counterterrorism operations have weakened the TTP. The group remains active under the leadership of Maulana Fazlullah.

description: The Moroccan Islamic Combatant Group (GICM) is an Islamic militant group established in the mid- to late-1990's. description: Armed Communist Formations (FCA) was a small short-lived, left-wing Italian group active primarily in Milan, Florence, and Rome, beginning in 1975. It had at most two dozen members. The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) were a militant separatist group fighting for an independent homeland for Hindu Tamils in Northeastern Sri Lanka. The LTTE was founded in the early 1970s by Velupillai Prabhakaran, who led the group until his death by Sri Lankan armed forces in May 2009. During the 1980s, the LTTE defeated a number of different Tamil militant groups, emerging as the dominant group by the end of the decade. The LTTE successfully carried out a number of high-profile attacks, including the assassination of two heads of state. The LTTE were  also notorious for their use of suicide terrorism, perpetrated by their elite suicide bombing unit known as the Black Tigers. Starting in 1985, the LTTE began negotiations with the Sri Lankan government; however, multiple rounds of negotiations failed and were interrupted by bouts of violence and clashes between both sides. In March 2004, a large faction of the LTTE led by Colonel Karuna defected, significantly weakening the organization. In 2006, after another failed round of negotiations, the Sri Lankan government declared all-out war on the LTTE and the group was militarily defeated in May 2009.

description: March 28 Brigade was a Milan-based left-wing terrorist group. It formed in 1979 as Red Guerrilla but changed its name to March 28 Brigade in response to the death of four Red Brigades militants in a firefight with Italian military police on March 28, 1980. The new group comprised former members of other left-wing groups, principally Communist Combat Formations (FCC), Communist Combat Units (UCC), and Communist Brigades (BC). March 28 Brigade militants sought to overthrow the Italian state and replace it with a dictatorship of the proletariat, and to that end hoped to gain credibility for their movement through attacks with the goal of establishing ties to the Red Brigades. It is unclear whether it succeeded; all of its members had been arrested by the end of 1980.

National Front (FN) was one of Italy's three main neo-fascist terrorist groups established before the 1970s. It was led by Prince Junio Borghese, a military veteran and former leader of a right-wing political party. Many of its other members were also veterans who had served Italy's fascist regime and never accepted Italian democracy. The group had both defensive and offensive aims, seeking to guard against Communism as well as to provoke or stage a fascist coup. The group had deep ties to the other main right-wing groups of the period, New Order (ON) and National Vanguard (AN). Their membership overlapped and the three groups jointly planned a coup attempt, ultimately aborted, in 1970. FN dissolved and many of its members fled abroad after the group was banned by authorities in the mid-1970s. Its remnants, along with those of AN and ON, were thereafter subsumed into Black Order, another neo-fascist terrorist group.

National Vanguard (AN) was one of three main neo-fascist Italian terrorist groups to form prior to the mid-1970s, along with New Order (ON) and National Front (FN). It broke from ON in 1960 but continued to collaborate with the group. Like the other neo-fascist groups, AN sought to stage or provoke a fascist coup in Italy, and to protect Italy from a feared Communist takeover. In the longer term, AN sought to unite all of Europe into one totalitarian nation. The group had deep ties to the ON and the FN. Their membership overlapped and the three groups jointly planned a coup attempt, ultimately aborted, in 1970. AN dissolved and many of its members fled abroad after the group was banned by authorities in the mid-1970s. Its remnants, along with those of ON and FN, were afterward subsumed into another neo-fascist group, Black Order.

The right-wing New Order (ON) was the first major terrorist group to emerge in Italy after World War II. It was a militant offshoot of right-wing parliamentary party Italian Social Movement (MSI). It sought to overthrow Italian democracy and reinstate a fascist regime. It spawned other neo-fascist terrorist groups, notably National Vanguard (AN), and along with AN and National Front (FN), it was one of the three main neo-fascist terrorist groups in post-World War II Italy. ON, AN, and FN had deep ties; their membership overlapped and they frequently collaborated on attacks, most notably an aborted coup attempt in 1970. ON dissolved when it was banned in the mid-1970s, and was thereafter subsumed into Black Order along with remnants of FN and AN.

description: Revolutionary Action (AR) was Italy's primary anarchist terrorist group. It was organized loosely into "affinity groups" based on personal ties and ideological sympathy between members. Some of these groups embraced feminist objectives in addition to the group's core anarchist goals. Of the group's few attacks, most targeted Italy's major newspapers, especially the Turin daily "La Stampa," as part of a planned national campaign against the media's purported manipulation of public opinion. Like most of Italy's leftist terrorist groups, AR also targeted the center-right Christian Democrat party. After the group dissolved itself in 1981, some of its members joined Prima Linea.

Revolutionary Action Movement (MAR) was a neo-fascist Italian terrorist group active in the early 1970s. It sought to stage a fascist coup. It was led by Carlo Fumagalli, a veteran who had actually fought against the fascists in World War II and later worked for Italian and U.S. intelligence agencies. The group cooperated closely with Black Order. It dissolved when Fumagalli and several other members were arrested.

The Compass (Rosa dei Venti, RDV) was an early neo-fascist group based in northern Italy with its headquarters in Padua. Like other militant groups on the right, it sought to overthrow the Italian state and replace it with a fascist regime, using terrorism as a tactic to cast suspicion on the left and prompt state repression. Its membership included retired officers of Mussolini's army as well as common criminals. It was also suspected of ties to Italian public figures and secret service members through the Masonic Lodge Propaganda Due. It was active for only five years before most of its leadership was arrested.

Third Position (TP) originated from neo-fascist groups but blended right-wing and left-wing rhetoric. TP sought the violent overthrow of the Italian government and advocated a "fascist dictatorship of the proletariat," but its exact goals were unclear. The group staged terrorist attacks in addition to acting as the semi-legal political wing of Armed Revolutionary Nuclei (NAR), a right-wing group that emerged from New Order. TP ended with the arrest of several of its leaders while they were transferring weapons.

The Union of Communist Combatants (UdCC) was one of several offshoots of the Red Brigades, Italy's largest left-wing terrorist groups. The Union of Communist Combatants split from the main successor to the Red Brigades, the Red Brigades Fighting Communist Party (BR-PCC) in early 1986. The UdCC shared broad revolutionary goals with the BR and its other successors but differed with those groups over how the armed struggle should be conducted. UdCC's formation was the first split in the organization of the second half of the 1980s, and it would be the last as the Red Brigades and all of its offshoots had been broken up by law enforcement by 1988.

Armed Proletarian Nuclei (NAP) was Southern Italy's most powerful left-wing terrorist organization in the early 1970s. NAP fought against capitalism and promoted a classless society in Italy. The group focused on prisons as the ultimate symbol of state repression and had operational cells both within and outside of prisons. It struck an alliance with the Red Brigades in 1976 and dissolved soon afterward; the Red Brigades absorbed some of its remaining members and assets.

description: Jemaah Islamiyah (JI) is an Islamist extremist organization based in Indonesia. The group seeks to establish an Islamic caliphate extending across Southeast Asia. It originated in the late 1980s and was responsible for a number of high-profile attacks that mainly targeted Christians and Western interests throughout the 1990s and early 2000s, including the 2002 Bali nightclub bombings that killed over 200. Following increased security efforts and internal splintering in the mid-2000s, JI has become less active.

description: The Caucasus Emirate was founded in 2007 by the last President of the Republic of Ichkeria, Doku Umarov. He dissolved the Chechen Republic of Ichkeria in order to create an overarching organization, which would incorporate all the other major and small-scale terrorist groups in the North Caucasus. The Caucasus Emirate has maintained strong ties with Al Qaeda and the Taliban. They allow training camps in the North Caucasus and send fighters to train in Al Qaeda-sponsored training camps.

description: Black Order was a right-wing militant group that absorbed many of the members of the major fascist militant groups that were banned in the mid-1970s. It may also have absorbed smaller right-wing militant groups such as La Fenice and Mussolini Action Squads. Like its predecessors, Black Order sought either to stage a fascist coup or provoke one through a so-called "strategy of tension," in which terrorism could prompt harsh state repression. Black Order claimed two high-casualty bombings in 1974, the first at a rally in Brescia and the second on a train, which killed four and twelve people respectively.

Armed Revolutionary Nuclei (NAR) was the main right-wing terrorist group of the second half of the 1970s. It became active shortly after Italy's "first generation" of right-wing terrorist groups, active from the mid-1950s to the mid-1970s, dissolved with the arrest of many of their members. NAR was perhaps the most active and violent of the neo-fascist groups, carrying out a large number of individual woundings and assassinations as well as claiming responsibility for the worst terrorist bombing in Italian history, which killed 85.

description: Al Jamaa Al-Islamiya is an Egyptian Sunni Islamist movement who seeks to overthrow the Egyptian government and install a Muslim government. The group became active as an umbrella group for student militant groups in Egypt during the 1970s, seeking to restore Islam in the government. The group carried out a major terror campaign in the mid-1990s, killing more than 1,200 people in several major attacks.

Communists organized for Proletarian Liberation (COLP) was the larger of two groups to split from Prima Linea, the second-largest left-wing terrorist group in Italy. It had roughly 150 members and operated chiefly in Northern and Central Italy. COLP broke off when PL declined due to increasing arrests of its members. COLP aimed to free PL members and other left-wing militants from prison. It was the main successor to the PL after the PL itself dissolved, but it fell apart with the arrest of most of its members soon afterward.

Communist Combat Formations (FCC) was among Italy's four largest and most active left-wing terrorist groups. It was active primarily in Northern Italy during the late 1970s. The FCC formed in Milan when members of a left-wing magazine, "Rosso," decided to take up arms. The FCC shared broad revolutionary goals with other left-wing terrorist groups, the two largest being the Red Brigades (BR) and Prima Linea (PL). The chief aim of all these groups was to overthrow the state and replace it with a dictatorship of the proletariat. The FCC however grew to only slightly over a hundred members and claimed a few dozen attacks, in contrast to the BR and the PL, which claimed thousands of members and hundreds of attacks between them. The group dissolved due to arrests. Some of its members joined the BR and some gave up the armed struggle altogether.

Let's Take Action (CA) was one of three main right-wing groups to form in and around Rome in the late 1970s. It sought the overthrow of the Italian state but was less anti-communist than its predecessors; it attempted, unsuccessfully, to build an anti-state coalition with left-wing groups. CA's main actions were forms of "armed propaganda," including attacks on government buildings. CA also published a right-wing journal that aimed to provide an intellectual reference point for other right-wing groups. The group dissolved when some of its leaders were arrested.

Communist Combat Units (UCC) formed from a split in the Armed Communist Formations (FCA) in 1976. It lasted longer and was larger than the earlier group. It was active primarily in Northern and Central Italy between the summers of 1976 and 1977. Its chief targets were small and medium-sized enterprises, which it blamed for exploiting workers. Beginning in 1977, the group began to split up; several members joined Prima Linea while others gave up their arms altogether.

Communist Revolutionary Committees (CoCoRi) was an Italian left-wing terrorist group with close to a hundred members active in Northern and Central Italy, chiefly the cities of Milan, Rome, and Padua. It had a legal as well as a militant wing and embraced a number of causes and activities without a necessarily consistent theme or goal, including protesting black market labor and heroin trafficking. Like other Italian leftist terrorist organizations, it committed attacks under a variety of names. The group primarily targeted law enforcement and security personnel and committed robberies to finance itself. The group dissolved its legal wing at a conference in mid-1978. Thereafter, some members considered joining Prima Linea but dissolved the entire organization instead.

Red Barbagia (BarbRo) was a left-wing and separatist terrorist organization based on the Italian island of Sardinia. It sought to make Sardinia an independent communist state. Red Barbagia mostly attacked and killed Italian military police in line with its stated campaign against the "militarization" of the island. It had logistical and operational ties to the Red Brigades (BR), Italy's largest left-wing terrorist organization, and may have staged attacks on the BR's behalf. BarbRo dissolved in 1982 after a repentant former BR member led law enforcement to a BR arms cache being guarded by members of BarbRo.

Venetian Collectives for Worker Power (CPV) was a left-wing terrorist group based exclusively in the northeastern Italian region of Veneto. CPV emerged from a legal left-wing organization, Worker Power, which had dissolved in 1973. Among its chief concerns was job insecurity, which it viewed as a central feature of modern capitalism. CPV was also anti-fascist. The group was composed largely of students and attacked mostly factory and university targets, though it is also known to have attacked other targets popular on the left, such as journalists, prisons, and real estate agencies.

The Communist Brigades (BC) were a left-wing terrorist group with nearly a hundred members active in Northern Italy. Like many other left-wing terrorist groups, it grew from legal left-wing groups. It was not so much a strict organization as a name used by militants to claim attacks. Its members embraced a variety of not necessarily connected goals, including fighting against heroin trafficking and stopping illegal work. The BC also attacked targets including law enforcement, prisons, business executives, and the center-right political party, the Christian Democrats. The group split up over members' differing opinions on how to organize the armed struggle. Some members formed the more-organized Communist Combat Formations beginning in 1977; others joined Prima Linea or other left-wing groups.

Communist Attack Divisions (RCA) was a small, left-wing group of about two dozen members active in Milan in Northern Italy. It split from the Communist Combat Formations (FCC), a larger left-wing group, in 1978. Its chief concern was the prisons, though it also at one point attacked a radio station. The group ceased to exist after most of its members were arrested beginning in 1980.

The Communist Territorial Nuclei (NCT) was a left-wing Italian terrorist group with a few dozen members based in Turin in Northern Italy. NCT sought to create a a proletarian army to control territory in Turin, presumably with the goal of imposing a communist system there, though it is unclear whether the group wanted Turin to secede from Italy. It committed a small number of attacks, mostly sabotage against Fiat factories. Like many Italian leftist terrorist groups, NCT was broken up by arrests, and its remaining members joined other armed organizations.

Nucleus of Communists (NdC) was one of two groups, along with Communists Organized for Proletarian Liberation (COLP), to split from Prima Linea (PL), the second-largest terrorist group in Italy, as the group began to decline due to increasing arrests. NdC and COLP broke off as the PL began to decline due to increasing arrests. Like the PL, NdC's primary aim was to liberate left-wing militants from prison. The group ended when all of its members were arrested in early 1983.

The Balochistan Liberation Army (BLA) is an ethnonationalist militant organization, comprised mostly of Marri and Bugti tribe members, fighting against the Pakistani government for greater regional autonomy for the province of Balochistan. The organization was founded in 2000 and has used IEDs, mortar strikes, ethnic genocide, and small arms attacks against Pakistani government affiliates, Punjabi, and foreign workers in Balochistan.

The Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF) is the largest militant organization in the Philippines, and it seeks autonomy for Filipino Muslims. The MILF split from the Moro National Liberation Front (MNLF) in 1977, although it was generally inactive and did not call itself the MILF until 1984. The MILF controls territory in the southern Philippines, governing with Shariah law. It has generally focused on political negotiation, but it has a significant history of terrorism and militancy. In 2014, the MILF concluded peace negotiations with the Philippine government for an autonomous region in the southern Philippines, to be called the Bangsamoro. The MILF is in the process of gradual disarmament.

description: The Irish People's Liberation Organization (IPLO) split from the Irish National Liberation Army (INLA) after the assassination of an INLA leader threw the organization's command structure into disarray. Like INLA, IPLO sought to unite Northern and Southern Ireland into a socialist republic independent of the United Kingdom. IPLO considered itself the legitimate custodian of this goal and sought to destroy and replace INLA. IPLO was soon forcibly dissolved by the Provisional Irish Republican Army (PIRA), the main Catholic independence-seeking group in Northern Ireland, which killed and injured a number of the group's members in a Halloween attack. Some IPLO members then rejoined INLA.

The Irish National Liberation Army (INLA) was a socialist paramilitary group that served as the armed wing of the Irish Republican Socialist Party (IRSP). INLA sought to unify Ireland as a socialist republic independent from the United Kingdom. Many of the group's founders were former members of the Official Irish Republican Army (OIRA), one of the two main Catholic paramilitary groups in Northern Ireland seeking Irish independence, who did not support a ceasefire OIRA declared in 1972. INLA targeted mostly British and local security forces, though one of its most famous actions was the December 1997 killing of a Protestant paramilitary leader in prison, and the group also killed a large number of civilians. The group declared a ceasefire in 1998 and formally renounced violence in 2009, saying it could now achieve its goals through peaceful means.

The Official Irish Republican Army (OIRA) is one of two splinter groups that broke away from the Irish Republican Army (IRA) in 1969 (the other being the Provisional Irish Republican Army (PIRA)). OIRA was by far the less violent of the two IRA offshoots, initially intending to lead a defensive united class struggle and avoid militant republicanism. It conducted mostly small attacks against British forces in an effort to unite and free Northern Ireland from England. OIRA declared a ceasefire in 1972, after which its violent activity dropped off dramatically, with most of its members becoming involved in socialist politics through the Workers' Party. The organization continued to stage isolated attacks at least until 1979, however, and did not fully decommission its weapons until February 2010.

description: The Real Irish Republican Army (rIRA) was the most violent of the groups to split from the Provisional Irish Republican Army (PIRA) in protest over the PIRA's ceasefires and participation in the peace process. The rIRA split from PIRA in 1997 and aimed to force a British withdrawal from Northern Ireland and unify Northern and Southern Ireland. Among its targets were British soldiers, Northern Ireland police forces, and civilians. Within a year of forming, rIRA staged the bloodiest attack of the modern Northern Ireland conflict with a car bombing in the town of Omagh in August 1998 that killed 29. In the face of public outrage over the attack, the rIRA declared a ceasefire a month later. The group resumed attacks in England and Northern Ireland in 2000. While the Real IRA has not mounted a large-scale attack since 1998, it engaged in hundreds of smaller attacks throughout the twenty-first century, including bombings, shootings, kidnappings, and more. During this time, the group declined due to widespread arrests and did not carry out a fatal attack since killing two British soldiers in 2009. In 2012, the Real IRA merged with three other dissident Republican groups to form the New IRA.

description: Óglaigh na hÉireann (ONH2) was one of two republican paramilitary splinter groups to operate separately under the same name in the 2000s. The exact date of ONH2s formation is unclear. Most sources claim that ONH2s original foundation was laid when dozens of Real IRA (rIRA) imprisoned leaders called for a ceasefire and split from Real IRA (rIRA) leadership in 2002. However, the group did not become active until 2008, when it murdered a member of rIRA.  The group aims for British withdrawal from Northern Ireland and the unification of Ireland. The name "Óglaigh na hÉireann" means "Volunteers of Ireland" and has also been used by several other factions of the Irish Republican Army (IRA) throughout IRA history. The group came to national prominence in 2009 after claiming responsibility for several bombings targeting police officers. They continued this campaign of attacking and PSNI and British Police officers. In 2018, the group announced it had entered a ceasefire. In 2019, the death of ONH2s leader spurred most former members to merge with the New IRA.

The Provisional Irish Republican Army (PIRA) was the main republican paramilitary organization in Northern Ireland. It sought to force the withdrawal of the British and establish a unified Ireland. The PIRA formed in 1969 after a split in the Irish Republican Army, a paramilitary organization that had fought for the establishment of the Republic of Ireland in the south. In Northern Ireland, the Provisionals split from the core of the Irish Republican Army, which came to be known as the Official Irish Republican Army (OIRA), accusing its leadership of neglecting the military aspect of the Irish struggle in favor of a failing political strategy. PIRA targeted British security forces [...]

The Continuity Irish Republican Army (CIRA) split from the Provisional Irish Republican Army (PIRA) when the PIRA dropped its longstanding opposition to the participation of its political wing, Sinn Fein, in the Parliament of Northern Ireland.  CIRA continued to view the Northern Ireland Parliament as illegitimate since it did not represent the whole of Ireland. The CIRA claimed to be the true republican group and sought to create a unified Ireland independent of Britain. The CIRA did not stage its first attacks until after the PIRA declared a ceasefire in 1994. Thereafter it targeted Protestant civilians and Northern Ireland police. To date, the group has only killed one police officer. After the creation of the New IRA in 2012, CIRA remained the only main independent republican militant in Northern Ireland. The group remains weak and has not attracted more than a few dozen members.

Óglaigh na hÉireann (ONH1) was one of two Provisional Irish Republican Army (PIRA) splinter groups to operate separately under the same name after 2005. ONH1 was the first two emerge but the less active of the two, having effectively fallen apart by the time the other ONH, ONH2, rose to prominence in 2009. ONH1 split from the Continuity Irish Republican Army (CIRA) in 2005 or 2006 for reasons that are unclear. Like all republican paramilitary groups descended from the Irish Republican Army (IRA), it sought the withdrawal of the British from Northern Ireland and the unification of Northern and Southern Ireland. ONH1 targeted political figures and police officers, though the only murder attributed to the organization was that of a former Real Irish Republican Army (rIRA) member in 2008.

Tara was a Unionist movement that strongly opposed a united Ireland. The group was known for its anti-Catholic views and also promoted an extreme sect of Evangelical Protestantism. Its loyalism to the United Kingdom drew the group closer to the Ulster Volunteer Force (UVF) and the Red Hand Commando (RHC). Its relationship with UVF was not consistent, due to tension over UVF proposals for Catholic-Protestant working-class solidarity. Tara's downfall can be linked with the multiple scandals involving its leader, William McGrath, including child sex abuse and illegal arms shipment. By the end of 1981, the group was practically disbanded.

The Ulster Volunteer Force (UVF) was a loyalist, paramilitary organization that was created after the 50th anniversary of the Easter Rising (1916). The anniversary reflected a revival in sentiments for an independent Northern Ireland. The UVF declared war on the IRA and its splinter groups. It is most well-known for its involvement in the Troubles, which included thirty years of bombings and killings of Irish republicans and Catholics. In total, the group was responsible for over 500 deaths. In May of 2007, the group vowed to become a "non-military, civilianized" organization.

Protestant Task Force (PTF) was a small armed group active in the 1970s opposed to Northern Irish secession from the United Kingdom. The group claimed to target Catholics associated with the Irish Republican Army (IRA), which sought to wrest Northern Ireland from British control and unite it with the Republic of Ireland in the south. It is unclear whether the PTF committed any purely sectarian killings. The group claimed its members were exclusively former members of the British military, and is alleged to have received support from, or to have been controlled by, British Intelligence.

The Loyalist Volunteer Force (LVF) split from the mid-Ulster Brigade of the UVF. Billy Wright created the LVF in 1996 together with Alex Kerr, a former UDA brigadier from South Belfast. Like other established paramilitary organizations, the LVF was given its own prison wing and used this as a vehicle for recruitment. The LVF went on to become one of the most violent and volatile paramilitary organization of the post-ceasefire period, killing 18 people (both catholics and protestants).  In further defiance of the Belfast UVF leadership, the LVF collaborated with Johnny Adairs C Company Battalion of the UDA during the loyalist feuds. Together, members of the LVF and Adairs C Company used a variety of cover names for violence they carried out in the early 2000s: Red Hand Defenders, Loyalist Freedom Fighters, and Orange Volunteers.  Wright was killed in prison by the INLA in 1997, and the UVF leadership declared that it had ended its arms campaign in 2005.

Red Hand Commando (RHC) was a small loyalist paramilitary group. Its chief aim was to maintain Northern Ireland as part of the UK, and to oppose by force the republican movement that aimed to make Northern Ireland part of a unified Ireland free of British control.  RHC was closely allied to the Ulster Volunteer Force (UVF), one of the largest loyalist paramilitary groups in Northern Ireland. The two groups had separate command structures but shared weapons and moved together on major political issues, jointly engaging in the peace process and ultimately decommissioning their weapons in 2009. The UVF and RHC together are believed to be responsible for over 500 deaths in the course of the modern Northern Ireland conflict, mainly of Catholic civilians.

The Orange Volunteers (OV2) were a small Ulster loyalist Protestant group created in 1998. OV2 was not associated with the group labeled the 1970's 'Orange Volunteer' group, which shared the same name. The group formed after the 1998 Belfast Agreement and opposed the mass calls for Loyalist ceasefires. Since then, they engaged in multiple acts of violence and sectarian harassment, especially through the early 2000s. Their most prominent attack involved the simultaneous attack on 11 Catholic churches in Northern Ireland. The group's last known attack occurred in 2009; since then, the group has become largely inactive. Members of the Ulster Volunteer Force, Loyalist Volunteer Force & UDA have used the OV name as a cover organization.

The Shankill Defense Association was one of the largest early loyalist vigilante groups in Belfast, the capital of Northern Ireland. Its stated goal was to protect Protestant/Loyalist neighborhoods from Catholic/Republican attacks, though the SDA is also believed to have pressured Catholics to move out of predominantly Protestant neighborhoods. Many of its members also served in the Ulster Special Constabulary, a loyalist volunteer paramilitary force organized by the British to maintain order. SDA was a precursor of the larger, more organized Loyalist Protestant paramilitaries. The SDA and similar Protestant neighborhood defense associations later merged to form the core of the Ulster Defense Association (UDA), which became the largest loyalist paramilitary group in Northern Ireland.

The Ulster Citizen Army (UCA) was a small, short-lived splinter group of the Ulster Defense Association (UDA). Like the UDA, it was a Protestant loyalist organization that sought to prevent the secession of Northern Ireland from the United Kingdom, but it espoused a more left-wing and less anti-Catholic outlook than its parent organization.

The Ulster Defense Association (UDA) was formed in 1971 from a number of neighborhood watch groups and vigilante organizations in Belfast. After emerging in response to the outbreak of "the Troubles," the UDA quickly became the largest loyalist paramilitary organization and remained so throughout the Troubles.  Its goal was to defend Protestant loyalist areas and combat Irish republican dissident groups. The UDA used the Ulster Freedom Fighters (UFF) name as a cover for sectarian killings. Despite the well-established relationship, the UDA itself was not listed as a proscribed organization until 1992. The UDA was a large and decentralized organization, led by an inner council of six regionally-based leaders, each with veto power. After failing to follow through on its 1994 ceasefire, the UDA finally decommissioned its arsenal in 2010.

The Red Hand Defenders (RHD) is a Loyalist paramilitary group. There is speculation that RHD has also been used as a cover name for members of other terrorist organizations in Northern Ireland, namely the Loyalist Volunteer Force (LVF) and the Ulster Defense Association (UDA). It is not clear to what extent the name RHD represented a distinct organization at different points in time. The RHD has conducted attacks using pipe bombs, grenades and hand guns against Catholic families located Northern Ireland and continues to fight for a continued British Rule.

Emerging from the Irish Republican Brotherhood (the rebel group that staged the Easter Rising in 1916), the Irish Republican Army (IRA) became the military wing of the Sinn Féin party. The party's platform promoted an independent Northern Ireland, free from British rule. In the Irish War of Independence 1919-21, the IRA fought the British using guerrilla warfare. It lost support because of its pro-Germany stance in WWII and its increased use of violence. After becoming a covert organization, it split into two groups in 1969: The Provisional Irish Republican Army (PIRA) and the Official Irish Republican Army (OIRA). The PIRA adopted a more violent approach to change than did the OIRA. Since the OIRA's ceasefire in 1972, the PIRA has been identified as the "IRA."

Movement 2 June, the second most prominent left-wing German urban guerrilla group of the 1970s, was founded by former members of Kommune I, and was based in West Berlin. The group mostly bombed property targets in Berlin. It was named after the date when a young pacifist named Benno Ohnesorg was killed by police during a 1967 protest in Berlin. They occasionally partnered with the Red Army Faction. Movement 2 June achieved its greatest victory in 1975 when it kidnapped Peter Lorenz, the CDU candidate for Berlin mayor in the upcoming election. Movement 2 June disbanded early in the 1980s, with many of its members joining the Red Army Faction.

The Revolutionary Cells (Revolutionäre Zellen) was formed in Frankfurt am Main around 1972-1973. They rejected the Baader-Meinhof Gangs approach to group dynamics. Instead of completely going underground, they organized into semi-autonomous cells, each aware of the groups overall mission yet mostly unaware of the identities of other group members. Virtually all of the members of Revolutionary Cells were legals  part-time operatives who otherwise maintained legal jobs and had families. They were said to number in the several hundred at one point in the mid-1980s, but precise numbers remain unclear.

Red Zora, or Rote Zora, was a feminist splinter group of the Revolutionary Cells that targeted sex shops, embassies, and factories that it believed to be contributing to the oppression of women. While it used bombings in its attacks, it intentionally avoided causing casualties.

The Red Army Faction, or the Baader-Meinhof gang, was a violently anti-capitalist branch of the radical student movement in the late 1960s. It carried out a campaign against the German elite and U.S. military personnel that killed over thirty. The group robbed banks and used bombings and assassinations as standard tactics. It dissolved on April 20th, 1998.

Kataib Hezbollah (KH), also known as the Hezbollah Brigades, is a Shiite Iraqi insurgent group in Iraq and Syria that was founded in 2007. The group is led by Abu Mahdi al-Muhandis and receives large amounts of training, logistical support, and weapons from the Iranian Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps (IRGC).  From 2007-2011, KH directed the majority of its attacks against U.S.-Coalition forces in Iraq and was designated as a foreign terrorist organization by the U.S. on July 2, 2009. Following the U.S. withdrawal from Iraq in 2011, KH sent large numbers of its fighters to Syria to fight alongside Hezbollah and the Assad government. KH has also deployed its troops in Iraq to fight the Islamic State (IS) and is a member of the Popular Mobilization Forces (PMF), an umbrella group of Shiite militant groups fighting IS in Iraq.

HN was founded by Mujahideen commander Jalaluddin Haqqani in the late 1970s, and rose to prominence in the anti-Soviet war in the 1980s. The core structure of HN is largely familial and hierarchical. HNs primary goals are to expel foreign forces, increase influence over new territory, and restore Taliban rule. HN employs a variety of tactics including violence, co-option, and infiltration of local security forces and government structures to consolidate its power and support Taliban, Al Qaeda, and other state and non-state actors.

description: The Yarmuk Jamaat began in mid-2002 in Kabardino-Balkaria under Muslim Atayev. His death in 2004  prompted Anzor Astemirov, who would be a leading figure in the Caucasus Emirate, to lead the Jamaat. They wanted to establish the independence of Kabardino-Balkaria from the Russian Federation. The Jamaat is most known for the failed Nalchik raid in 2005. In 2007, the Yarmuk Jamaat no longer functioned as an independent entity; they became  members of the newly established Caucasus Emirate upon its creation in 2007.

The Ingush Jamaat began in 2000 by Ingush rebels who aimed to achieve independence from Russia.  To achieve this goal the group collaborated with other prominent terrorist groups in the North Caucasus.The Ingush Jamaats most prominent attack was the Nazran Raid in 2004 led by rebel Shamil Basayev, who became an integral part of several terrorist organizations, including the Caucasus Emirate.  The Ingush Jamaat, like other terrorist groups functioning out of the North Caucasus, became a member of the Caucasus Emirate upon its creation in 2007.

Shariat Jamaat began in 2002 in Dagestan. The Shariat Jamaat was known for its violent tactics, especially the use of suicide bombers in and around Dagestan. Like the Ingush and Yarmuk Jamaats, the Shariat Jamaart sought independence from the Russian Federation. In order to establish independence the Shariat Jamaat worked with the other terrorist groups emanating from the North Caucasus. With the creation of the Caucasus Emirate in 2007 the Shariat Jamaat no longer functioned by itself, rather they became a part of the Caucasus Emirate.

The Liberation Army of Dagestan was formed in 1999. This radical group took responsibility for the apartment building bombings in Moscow, Russia in September 1999.  Later investigation showed that the Liberation Army of Dagestan was linked to the Islamic Army of Dagestan led by Al-Khattab and Shamil Basayev, which was responsible for the invasion of Dagestan in 1999. Like other terrorist groups functioning out of the North Caucasus the Liberation Army of Dagestan wanted to establish an independent region (Dagestan) from the Russian Federation. There is limited information about this group, but it is known that the group is now defunct and its members function within the Caucasus Emirate.

The Moro National Liberation Front (MNLF) is an Islamic separatist organization based in the southern Philippines that seeks autonomy for Filipino Muslims, called Moros. The MNLF was established in 1972, and it led the Moro separatist movement until the 1996 Final Peace Agreement between the MNLF and the Philippine government. Since 1996, the MNLF has been surpassed in strength and influence by its rival group, the Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF), which began its own peace talks with the Philippine government. Today, the MNLF consists of many factions, some of which support current negotiations between the Philippine government and the MILF.

description: Members of the West Berlins Kommune I formed a low-level urban guerrilla group called Tupamaros West Berlin (TW) in mid-1969. After the group disbanded, the core members founded the Movement 2 June. Another low-level urban guerrilla group called Tupamaros Munich was also formed during the late sixties, but also disbanded without causing much harm. TW was a small German Marxist militant organization which carried out a series of bombings and arson attacks against the state of the Federal Republic of Germany. Their attacks were centered in West-Berlin. The group was active between the fall of 1969 and the beginning of the 1970s.

The SPK was created by Dr. Wolfgang Huber, a staff member of the Heidelberg University, and promoted the idea that capitalism was the root cause of the mental and physical sickness in Germany. The group grew in numbers, much to the University's disapproval, until Huber was arrested in 1971 after the SPK began its low-scale attacks. The group was essentially dissolved, with members moving to activist groups and other terrorist groups in Germany.

Kommune 1 was a community of leftist protesters governed by a unique ideology linked to Maoism. Its members carried out political protests and publicity-driven stunts. It is most known for its attempted 1967 pudding assassination of U.S. Vice President Herbert Humphrey, in which members were arrested before they were able to throw plastic bags filled with yogurt, flour, and pudding at the vice president.

Al Qaeda Kurdish Battalions (AQKB) is a Kurdish, Salafi militant organization affiliated with Al Qaeda (AQ) that operates in Iraqi Kurdistan.  Since its formation in March 2007, the group has a primarily targeted the Kurdistan Regional Government. However, beginning in April 2014, AQKB may also be engaged fighting the Islamic State (IS).

description: The Supreme Council for Islamic Revolution in Iraq (SCIRI), known since 2009 as the Supreme Iraqi Islamic Council (ISCI), is a Shiite political party in Iraq with an active militant wing.  ISCI was established by Shiite exiles in Iran, who, in 1982, formed the group with a mission to overthrow Saddam Hussein and install an Iranian-style government. After Saddam Hussein was overthrown, the party quickly tried to establish power in Iraq under the guidance of its new leader, Abdul Aziz al-Hakim.   Al-Hakim led the group to increased power through a series of image reforms coupled with pragmatic political decisions to distance the group from its unpopular linkages with Iran and the United States.  One of the main ways that al-Hakim distanced the group from Iran was by switching its formal name to the Islamic Supreme Council of Iraq (ISCI); however, the group is still commonly referred to as SCIRI. ISICs militia is still active, and is by some estimates 10,000 strong. The militia mainly active in the north, where it has in recent years clashed with the British army and Mahdi forces. The group continues, to varying degrees, advocate a separate Shiite-run region in the oil-rich southern Iraq. In 2009, its leader al-Hakim died and was succeeded by his son, Ammar al-Hakim, but doubts remain about his ability to effectively lead the group.

In 1981, members of the Medellin Cartel, including Pablo Escobar and Carlos Ledher Rivas, established Muerte a Secuestradores (MAS), or in English, Death to Kidnappers. MAS started as a private army with 2,230 fighters, allied with the Colombian military to combat leftist guerrillas including the M-19, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC), the National Liberation Army (ELN), and the Popular Liberation Army (EPL). MAS grew to include many small paramilitary groups and became the blanket title for private armies that opposed leftist guerrilla groups.  In the late 1980s, MAS assassinated hundreds of Union Patriotica members, members of a political party sponsored by the FARC, and many April 19 Movement Democratic Alliance (AD M-19) party members, a party created by M-19 members after its demobilization. By the mid 1990s, MAS weakened in strength and numbers, and the United Self-Defense Forces of Colombia took MAS place as the largest paramilitary group in Colombia.

The Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan (IMU) is an Islamist militant group seeking to overthrow the Uzbek government and install an Islamic, Sharia-driven government. The group operates out of northern Afghanistan, conducting operations in Kyrgyzstan, Uzbekistan, and Tajikistan. With between 500-1000 members, the IMU is closely allied to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, and frequently conducts joint operations with the two organizations. More recent analysis of IMU activity suggests that they are working with groups to overthrow the current government of Pakistan. The IMU has its central bases in Tajikistan and Taliban-controlled parts of northern Afghanistan.

description: Tehreek Nifaz-e-Shariat Mohammadi is a Pakistani militant group whose goal is to enforce Shariah law in the Malakand Division of Pakistan, a region that includes Swat valley. Maulana Sufi Muhammad established the group after the Malakand insurgency in 1994 after gaining support from a court decision supporting Provincially Administered Tribal Areas as well as implementing an armed campaign to overtake government functions in Swat valley. The group pushed for a series of judicial reforms favoring Shariah law in their region. TNSM promotes boycotts of local elections, portraying the Pakistani government as Western-imposed.  With the U.S. invasion of Afghanistan in 2001, Sufi Muhammad led 10,000 TNSM fighters to aid the Taliban. In 2009, TNSM increased its hold on Swat valley with another offensive involving 4,000 TNSM militants. Under international pressure, the Pakistani government responded by sending 30,000 troops to try to reverse TNSMs offensive. Sufi Muhammad negotiated a truce with Pakistan over the conflict in Swat valley, in which the TNSM agreed to a two-year cease fire in return for implementation of Shariah law. The truce was viewed internationally as acquiescence to TNSM ideology.

The Badr Organization advocates for the creation of a separate Shiite region in Southern Iraq and is closely allied with Iran, receiving funding and support from the nation. The Badr Organization was founded as the militia wing of the Islamic Supreme Council of Iraq (ISCI), a Shiite political party that was formerly known as the Supreme Council for the Islamic Revolution (SCIRI). In 2012, the Badr Organization broke away from the ISCI to maintain ties with Iran after the ISCI attempted to disassociate from the nation.

description: Ansar Dine, translated as Defenders of the Faith, is an Islamic group founded in December 2011 by Iyad Ag Ghali.  The group aims to establish Shariah law across Mali and targets western civilians and peacekeepers. Ansar Dines ideology closely mirrors that of Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) and is reportedly a domestic front group for AQIM, though it has never been publicly recognized by AQIM as an official affiliate.  Ansar Dine is best known for its takeover of northern Mali with the National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad (MNLA), AQIM and the Mouvement pour lUnification et le Jihad en Afrique de lOuest (MUJAO) after the Malian coup of 2012. Ansar Dine occupied and implemented Shariah law in Timbuktu and its environs from June 2012 until January 2013, when the French military intervened.  In early July 2012, Ansar Dine made national headlines when it destroyed seven mausoleums in Timbuktu, which were part of a United Nations World Heritage site. The Macina Liberation Front (FLM) was allegedly formed as an affiliate to Ansar Dine for coordination of its operations in central and southern Mali.

description: The Movement for the Liberation of Azawad (MNLA) is a separatist militant organization that formed in October 2011 and is made up predominately of ethnic Tuaregs.  The MNLA aimed to establish a secular, independent state called Azawad, that historically contained the vast portion of desert including Timbuktu, Kidal, Gao and their environs in Mali. In mid January of 2012, the MNLA, armed with sophisticated military equipment from Libya, launched assaults on towns in northern Mali. In response to the Malian military coup in March 2012, the MNLA briefly allied itself with Ansar Dine (AD), the Mouvement pour lUnification et le Jihad en Afrique de lOuest (MUJAO), Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) and its semi-autonomous battalion, the Those Who Sign in Blood Brigade, to take advantage of the lack of rule of law and occupy northern Mali.  However shortly after the groups gained control of the north, this alliance ended and fighting broke out between the MLNA and the other militant groups, who wanted a united Mali with Shariah law rather than a secular, independent state of Azawad.  By the end of 2012, the MNLA had lost the vast majority of its northern territory.  In June 2013, the MNLA signed a ceasefire agreement with the Malian government, but broke it in September to continue to fight for the independence of Azawad.  The MNLA joined the Arab Movement for Azawad (MAA) and the High Council for the Unity of Azawad (HCUA) in an umbrella group called the Coordination of the Movements of Azawad (CMA) in November 2013. On June 20, 2015, after a long peace process, the MNLA, along with the HCUA and the MAA, as a part of the CMA, signed the Agreement on Peace and Reconciliation in Mali with the Malian government on political and institutional reforms related to defense and security.  Today, the MNLA continues as a political movement within Mali.

Lashkar-e-Islam (LeI) is a militant group operating out of the Khyber Agency of Pakistan. It started off as a sectarian group with anti-Barelvi leanings. description: Jundullah is an Islamist group based in Pakistan that seeks to overthrow Pakistani religious minorities and establish a strict Sunni theocracy. Jundallah is linked to Tehrik-i-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) and has carried out high profile attacks on Pakistani state assets and sectarian targets, such as Shi'ite and Christian places of worship. They are also known for attacks on civilians, such as an attack on a school in Peshawar that killed hundreds of children. In a leaked memo, the Pakistani government stated the group has a total of 12,000 to 20,000 fighters. However, according to Reuters, both Jundullah militants and Pakistani security officials dismissed the memo as not credible. The Ras Kamboni Brigade was an Islamist militia operating primarily in Jubaland, located in southern Somalia near the border with Kenya. It was founded sometime in the 2000s by Hassan Abdullah Hersi al-Turki, a former leader in an Islamist group called Al Ittihad Al Islamiya (AIAI) and its successor, the Islamic Courts Union (ICU). The Ras Kamboni Brigade fought against Somalias Transitional Federal Government (TFG) and foreign troops. In 2009, the group briefly merged with three other Islamist militant groups to form a new organization, Hizbul Islam. However, over the course of late 2009 and early 2010, the Ras Kamboni Brigade broke away from Hizbul Islam. The group split into two factions; one faction, led by al-Turki, joined Al Shabaab, and the other faction formed a new group, the Ras Kamboni Movement.

description: Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (Tahrir al-Sham), formerly known as Jabhat al-Nusra (Al-Nusra), is a Sunni opposition group that aims to overthrow the Assad Regime and establish an Islamic Emirate in Syria. Al-Nusra was formed in late 2011, when Al Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) emir Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi sent AQI operative Abu Muhammad al-Julani to Syria to organize regional jihadist cells. At its inception, Al-Nusra began harboring the Khorasan Group, a cell of approximately two-dozen experienced Al Qaeda (AQ) jihadists who were sent to Syria by central AQ leadership in order to develop international terror plots. However Al-Nusra began targeting the Islamic State (IS, formerly AQI) in January 2014 amid rising tensions between IS and the Sunni opposition forces. Throughout the conflict, the group has sought to cast itself as an irreplaceable military ally for opposition forces, and has a longstanding military partnership with Ahrar al-Sham.

description: The Colonel Karuna faction is a splinter group of the LTTE, led by former LTTE military commander Vinayagamoorthi Muralitharan, known commonly as Colonel Karuna. Colonel Karuna defected from the LTTE over suspicion that he was to be removed as commander of the LTTEs Eastern division and disagreement over LTTE operations in Northern Sri Lanka. The organizations military wing is called the Tamil National Front and its political wing is known as the Tamileela Makkal Viduthalai Pulligal (TMVP). By April 2004, the LTTE had subdued the breakway faction; however, Colonel Karuna escaped with a small group of supporters and regrouped in Colombo. In 2007, the TVMP was registered as an official political party, although the group continued to operate a military wing against the LTTE. On March 9, 2009, Colonel Karuna and his followers left the TVMP to join the Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SFLP), and Karuna was appointed the Minister of National Reconcilation and Integration.

description: The People's Liberation Organization of Tamil Eelam (PLOTE) was a militant Tamil separatist group fighting for an independent Tamil homeland in northeastern Sri Lanka. The group was founded by a former LTTE member and the two groups continued to clash until the military defeat of the LTTE in 2009. In the 1980s, PLOTE enjoyed the support of the Indian intelligence services (RAW); however, the group reached its military peak in 1985. Afterwards, RAW withdrew their support, and the LTTE launched a major offensive against PLOTE, causing the majority of its members to defect to the LTTE or be killed. Today, the PLOTE is a minor political party and small paramilitary force.

description: The Eelam National Democratic Liberation Front (ENDLF) was created in 1987 by the merger of Three Stars, a PLOTE splinter group led by Paranthan Rajan, and other ex-PLOTE and ex-EPRLF members. The merger was facilitated by RAW, the external unit of Indians Intelligence Services. After the IPKF left Sri Lanka in 1990, Rajan and the ENDLF shifted their base to India. In 2004, the ENDLF aligned itself with the anti-LTTE Karuna faction and actively recruited cadres for this group in refugee camps in Tamil Nadu, India. Today, the ENDLF is a pro-government paramilitary group and a minor political party.

The Tamil Eelam Liberation Organization (TELO) is a militant organization that fought for an independent homeland for Sri Lankas Tamils. TELO, which was officially founded in 1977, first entered into a cooperative alliance with the LTTE, as both were driven by the same fundamental goals. After the death of its co-founders in 1983, TELOs new leader Sri Sabaratnam reached out to RAW and established close ties with the external unit of the Indian Intelligence Services. With Indian funding, TELO grew in both numbers and capabilities. However, in April 1986, LTTE launched a full-out assault on TELO, which it now perceived as a moderate group. By May, the LTTE had successfully killed several hundred TELO cadres, as well as Sabaratnam. With little leadership structure and an over-reliance on Indian support, the organization was never able to re-emerge as a militant group. In 1987, TELO officially disbanded as a military organization and transitioned to a political party.

description: The Eelam Peoples Revolutionary Liberation Front (EPRLF) was created in 1979 when a faction of EROS, led by Douglas Devananda and others, broke away from the group due to an internal leadership dispute. EPRLF was committed to Marxist ideology and was mostly concerned with political mobilization and garnering grassroots support. After the 1983 anti-Tamil riots, however, the groups military wing came to the forefront and EPRLF transformed itself into a militant group. Between 1985-1986, the EPRLF developed rapidly, surpassing its predecessor EROS and bringing it into direct conflict with the LTTE. In 1985, EPRLF joined forces with TELO, EROS, and the LTTE to form the Eelam National Liberation Front (ENLF) to participate in the Thimphu peace talks brokered by India. In late 1986, after the failure of the talks, the LTTE launched an all-out assault on the EPRLF, forcing most of its members to surrender and effectively disbanding the military wing of the EPRLF. After its defeat by the LTTE, EPRLF aligned itself with the IPKF and transformed itself into a minor political party.

The Eelam Revolutionary Organization of Students (EROS) was one of the original separatist groups in Sri Lanka fighting for an independent Tamil state. EROS was founded in 1975 and acted initially as a think-tank researching Tamil issues. Soon thereafter, its leaders established ties with terrorist groups in the Middle East and Africa, such as the Palestinian Liberation Organization (PLO) and the African National Congress (ANC). EROS also organized the first terrorist training camps in Sri Lanka. EROS was the least violent and militarily active of the Tamil militant groups of the 1980s, although the group was responsible for a series of bombings in the mid-1980s and the kidnapping of a British journalist. As other Tamil groups began to emerge, EROS slowly lost its influence in the community. Eventually, the majority of EROS members defected to the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE). EROS ceased to be a militant movement when Shankar Rajee formed the EROS political party.

description: The Tamil Eelam Liberation Army (TELA) was the military wing of one of the formerly large Tamil militant groups, the Tamil Eelam Liberation Organization (TELO). In 1982, a small faction of TELA broke away from TELO, led by "Oberoi" Devan. Shortly after the split, TELA aligned itself with PLOTE, another Tamil militant group that had fought both the LTTE and TELO in the past. The group, however, was short-lived; after the death of Devan in 1983 by two suspected LTTE militants, the group went into decline. By 1985, TELA had succumbed to in-fighting, split into two, and was finally disbanded.

The Eelam National Liberation Front (ENLF) was an umbrella organization formed in April 1984 by EROS, TELO, and EPRLF. It is rumored that RAW, the external unit of the Indian intelligence services, sponsored the formation of the group. The ENLF did not constitute a formal merger of the groups but rather a "united forum" for the different militant groups to confront challenges and negotiate. In 1985, the LTTE joined the ENLF before their participation in the Thimpu peace talks with the Sri Lankan government. The talks, however, were short-lived and by September 1985, the Sri Lankan government resolved to end the Tamil conflict militarily. In 1986, the LTTE began eliminating other Tamil militant groups, leading to the disbanding of the ENLF. PLOTE was the only one of the "Big Five" groups of the 1980s not to be included in the ENLF merger.

Jaish al-Muhajireen wal Ansar (Muhajireen) was founded in February 2013 by Omar al-Shishani, a Chechen jihadist. The group, made up of foreign fighters, has launched joint assaults on Syrian military bases with the Islamic State of Iraq and the Sham (ISIS) and the al-Nusra Front. In fall 2013 the group splintered: al-Shishani and his faction joined ISIS, others joined the al-Nusra Front, and Salahuddin Shishani became the groups new commander. Many members of the Muhajireen are also affiliated with the Caucasus Emirate (CE).

Ahrar al-Sham also known as Harakat Ahrar al-Sham al-Islamiyya, or the Islamic Movement of the Free Men of the Levant, is a Sunni Salafist militant group established in late 2011 that aims to replace the Assad Regime with an Islamic government. The group operates throughout Syria but concentrates its attacks in the north and west of the country. From its inception in 2011 until late 2013, Ahrar al-Sham cooperated with the Islamic State (IS), and launched a successful campaign to remove the Syrian army from Raqqa. However, Ahrar al-Sham and Hay'at Tahrir al-Sham, formerly known as Jabhat al-Nusra (Al-Nusra), began targeting IS after it killed an Ahrar al-Sham member in January 2014. From 2014 through 2015, Ahrar al-Sham strengthened its alliance with Al-Nusra by coordinating attacks against the Syrian army and by creating the Jaysh al-Fatah umbrella group to force the Syrian army out of Idlib province in 2015. In August 2015, Ahrar al-Sham also began negotiating ceasefire agreements with the Assad Regime on behalf of the Sunni militant groups in Idlib. However, it has not participated in further negotiations since it left a conference on a nation-wide ceasefire in December 2015.

description: Suqour al-Sham was a Syrian opposition group that sought to replace the Assad Regime with an Islamic State. Ahmad Abu Eissa founded the group in Syrias Idlib governorate after his brothers were killed in armed civilian clashes with the Assad Regime in 2011. Through a series of mergers with smaller brigades, Suqour al-Sham quickly became one of the most powerful local opposition groups. Suqour al-Sham was active in multiple Syrian opposition coalitions, including the FSA linked Syrian Islamic Liberation Front (SILF) umbrella organization. However, the group began to distance itself from the FSA in 2013, and joined the Islamic Front umbrella group in November 2013. Although it was once one of the strongest groups in the Islamic Front, Suqour al-Shams strength declined after two of its most prominent brigades defected in order to avoid fighting the Islamic State (IS) and after IS assassinated Suqour al-Shams military commander. Suqour al-Sham signed a ceasefire with IS in February 2014, and after the dissolution of the Islamic Front in mid-2014, the group continued to coordinate intermittent attacks against the Assad Regime with Ahrar al-Sham and Al Qaeda affiliate Jabhat al-Nusra (Al-Nusra). In March 2015, Suqour al-Sham merged in to Ahrar al-Sham.

description: Liwa al-Tawhid (the Tawhid Brigade) was an Aleppo-based militant group that was formed by several small opposition brigades to fight the Assad Regime in July 2012. The groups goal was to replace the Assad Regime with a moderate Islamic state that had a basis in Shariah law, but included civilian rule, elections, and protection for minorities. Liwa al-Tawhid rose to prominence in July 2012 after becoming one of the first opposition groups to control territory in Aleppo. It was initially considered a member of the Free Syrian Army (FSA) and participated in the FSA-linked Syrian Islamic Front umbrella organization from January 2013 until November 2013, when Liwa al-Tawhid joined the Islamic Front umbrella group. Liwa al-Tawhid also cooperated with the Islamic State (IS) until January 2014, when it began targeting IS and temporarily drove IS out of the city of Aleppo. In July 2014, Liwa al-Tawhid, Ahrar al-Sham, and other former members of the Islamic Front, which dissolved in mid-2014, agreed to merge their Aleppo-based fighters and operate under the name Islamic Front. Since this merger, there have been conflicting reports on if Liwa al-Tawhid is still conducting operations independently.

The group was most known for its participation in a March 2014 offensive in Latakia that was lead by other opposition groups, such as Al-Nusra. After this offensive, Ansar al-Sham had few notable attacks and was mostly engaged in skirmishes with the Syrian army in Latakia. Following a series of skirmishes between opposition groups in the Idlib governorate, Ansar al-Sham joined Hay'at Tahrir al-Sham, formerly known as Jabhat Fatah al-Sham, on February 7, 2017.

description: Jaysh al-Islam (The Islam Army, The Islam Brigade) is a Syrian opposition group that aims to depose the Assad Regime. The group was formed in 2013 through a merger of about fifty Damascus-based opposition groups, and was initially lead by former Liwa al-Islam commander Zahran Alloush. The group operates in the Homs, Aleppo, Idlib, Hama, Daraa, and Quneitra governorates, and was an active member of the Islamic Front umbrella organization until the Islamic Front dissolved in 2014. Jaysh al-Islam opposes the Islamic State (IS) and has been battling the group since July 2014 when it first ousted IS from Eastern Ghouta in Damascus. Jaysh al-Islam has also had a tense relationship with former Al Qaeda affiliate Jabhat Fatah al-Sham, formerly known as Jabhat al-Nusra (Al-Nusra), ever since Al-Nusra rejected the authority of Jaysh al-Islams Unified Judiciary Council court system. Through late 2015 and early 2016, Jaysh al-Islams deteriorating ties with Al-Nusra and a series of other controversies have fueled political unrest in Eastern Ghouta.

description: The Kurdish Islamic Front (KIF) was founded by Islamic activist Sheikh Abu Abdullah al-Kurdi and the Syrian militant group Ahrar al-Sham in 2013. The KIF joined the Islamic Front, an alliance of Syrian opposition forces operating in the Syrian civil war. The KIF allegedly joined the Islamic Front to combat the impression that the Islamic Front's conflict with the Kurdish Popular Protection Units (YPG) was ethnically motivated. The KIF was the Islamic Fronts smallest member, and it began targeting the Assad Regime, the Islamic State, and the YPG as part of the Islamic Fronts offensives in early-2014 in northern Syria. The KIF fought alongside Ahrar al-Sham and adopted its ideologies and military goals. The group officially merged with Ahrar al-Sham after the Islamic Front fragmented in mid-2014.

The Free Syrian Army (FSA) was founded on July 29, 2011 by seven former members of the Syrian military, allegedly led by former air force Colonel Riad al-Asaad, who defected in order to fight the Assad Regime. The FSA is not a single cohesive armed opposition group, and the term is often used to refer to a loose alliance of moderate or secular opposition brigades that are fighting against the Assad Regime. In December 2012, the FSA created the Supreme Military Council (SMC, also known as The Council of Thirty) in an attempt to form a command structure among its brigades. The United States announced it would provide $123 million in non-lethal aid to the SMC in April 2013, and Saudi Arabia, The United Arab Emirates, Qatar, Jordan, and Turkey also agreed to give money and weapons to the SMC instead of directly funding individual FSA brigades. However tension arose in the SMC after a group of FSA leaders tried to replace SMC leader General Salim Idriss, and the FSAs National Coalition for Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces (National Coalition) ordered the SMC to dissolve in June 2014. Since the SMCs dissolution, it has been unclear if the FSA has an established command structure because the National Coalition has not endorsed any of the institutions proposed to replace the SMC; however, multiple media outlets still cite the FSA as an established group. Prominent FSA brigades include the 1st Coastal Division, Yarmouk Army, and the Northern Sun Battalion.

Ansar al-Shariah in Libya (ASL) is an Islamist militant group that formed in the aftermath of the Libyan uprising against Muammar el-Qaddafi in February 2011. ASL aims to establish a strict implementation of Shariah law in Libya, does not tolerate interpretations of Islam other than its own, and opposes democracy.  ASL fights the Libyan government and its armed forces, and at the same time seeks to gain popular support through extensive charitable actions in Libyan communities.  In 2013, ASL expanded its operations, effectively occupying territory in Benghazi, Derna, Sirte and Ajdabiya.  In February 2015, after the Libyan military targeted Islamist groups during Operation Dignity, ASL lost most of the territory it occupied to Libyan forces. As of March 3, 2016, ASL forces are currently fighting to defend their remaining strongholds in Ajdabiya, Benghazi and Derna.

description: Ansar al-Shariah in Tunisia (AST) is a Salafi-Jihadist militant organization established in 2011 that combines community service, proselytization, and violence to promote its Salafi ideology and goals in Tunisia.  The group aims to establish Shariah law in Tunisia and promotes the idea of global jihad.    The group targets the Tunisian government and armed forces, utilizing a dawa, or charitable works, campaign to gain trust among Tunisian communities.  Since its establishment, AST has supported Al Qaeda; however, in July 2014, ASTs spokesman, Seifeddine Rais, swore loyalty to IS.  It is unclear whether or not he spoke on behalf of AST or solely himself.

description: Jaysh al-Sham (Army of the Levant) was formed in January 2014 when Suyouf al-Haq, one of Suqour al-Shams strongest constituent brigades, defected due to fighting between Suqour al-Sham and the Islamic State (IS) and created a new group with former IS and Suqour al-Sham fighters. Jaysh al-Sham was prominent in Idlib province, where it opposed the Assad Regime but remained neutral to Suqour al-Sham and IS. This neutrality, along with threats from the Free Syrian Army, prompted the Liwa Dawoud brigade to leave IS and join Jaysh al-Sham in Feburary 2014. However, Liwa Dawoud reportedly left Jaysh al-Sham in July 2014 due either to threats from other opposition groups or internal tension with Jaysh al-Sham. Shortly after Liwa Dawoud defected, Jaysh al-Sham disbanded.

In 2002, Boko Haram was formed by Mohammad Yusuf as a Sunni Islamist sect that opposed western education and sought to establish an Islamic state in Nigeria. The group has carried out numerous attacks since 2009, including 2011 bombing of the U.N. headquarters in Abuja, but it is best known for the 2014 Chibok schoolgirl kidnapping, when the group abducted over 300 young Nigerian girls from a secular school. Its primary base of operation is northeastern Nigeria, but it has conducted limited operations in Cameroon and Niger. In March 2015, Boko Haram became an affiliate of the Islamic State (IS). In August 2016, IS announced Abu Musab al-Barnawi would assume leadership of Boko Haram. Shekau released statements that Barnawis followers were manipulating IS leadership in order to cut him off in a sort of coup; he said that he and his followers would not follow Barnawi, which reportedly led to splits within Boko Haram. It is currently unclear to what extent Shekau or Barnawi has power over Boko Haram militants, but the group remains affiliated with IS.

description: Jund al-Khilafah (JaK) is a Salafist militant group based in Algeria that aims to overthrow the Algerian government and establish a strict Sunni caliphate. In September 2014, Jund al-Khilafah split from al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) because they believe that AQIM had deviated from the true path. The group then declared allegiance to the Islamic State (IS) in September 2014, stating that militants in JaK would obey the orders of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the leader of IS. Almost immediately after this declaration, JaK threatened to behead a French citizen, Herve Gourdel, if the French government did not immediately halt air strikes on IS in Syria. The French government refused to comply, and JaK posted a video online of Gourdels beheading on September 24, 2014.

The Islamic State - Sinai Province (IS-SP, formally known as the Ansar Beit al-Maqdis) is a Salafi jihadist group formed following the toppling of Hosni Mubaraks regime in 2011 and focuses on operation in Egypt and the Gaza Strip. Founded as Ansar Beit al-Maqdis (ABM), the groups stated goal from 2011 to 2013 was to free Jerusalem from Western influence and rid Egypt of any Israeli presence. However, after the fall of Mohammed Morsis government in 2013, ABM shifted their focus to seek revenge against the Egyptian police and security forces for their violent crackdown on Muslim dissidents. IS-IP is also believed to be attempting to establish an Islamist province in the Sinai Peninsula run by the Islamic State. In November 2014, ABM pledged allegiance to the Islamic State and renamed itself the Islamic State  Sinai Province (IS-IP). In September 2015, the USA Terrorist Designation listed the Islamic State  Sinai Province as the groups official name. Other than this relationship, little is known about IS-IPs political or community goals. The group tends to have a local focus on the Sinai Peninsula and the Gaza Strip, and has claimed responsibility for many attacks within the region. Due to the Egyptian governments counterinsurgency crackdown on IS-IP, the organization mainly relies on bombings and assassinations to avoid direct contact with the better-equipped Egyptian army. IS-IP was responsible for attempting to assassinate the Egyptian Interior Minister in 2013, as well as a number of attacks on Egyptian soldiers and police.

description: On November 22, 2013, seven rebel factions in Syria announced the creation of the Islamic Front as a united opposition force against Syrian president Bashar al-Assad. Under the Islamic Front, these individual groups dissolved, providing a unified message of opposition to the government of al-Assad. The group released their charter on January 21, 2014. The stated goal of the organization is to overthrow the current regime and rebuild Syria on the sound bases of justice, independence and solidarity in accordance with the principles of Islam. While they believe that justice can only be brought through military rebellion, they also protect Syrian religious and ethnic minorities under Sharia law. Most recently, the Islamic Front has engaged in intense fighting with the Islamic State (IS) in northwest Syria. The Islamic Front is a predominantly Syrian organization, and much of the tension between the groups stems from the radical and alienating behavior of IS foreign fighters against the local Syrian population in rebel-held areas. For more information on the Islamic Front, visit the Syria Map.
These independent militant groups are the Islamist groups that formed during the Syrian Civil war as opposition to the Assad regime. Eventually, some of these groups merged to form the Islamic Front.

The Balochistan Republican Army (BRA) is an ethnonationalist separatist militant organization fighting against the Pakistani government for an independent Balochi State. The group was founded in 2006 and is mostly comprised of Bugti tribe members and young student political activists. The group uses mortar strikes, car bombs, IEDs, landmines, grenades, small-arms attacks, conventional warfare, unconventional warfare, social media, and nationalist propaganda to achieve its goal of creating an independent Balochi state. The BRA targets Pakistani security forces, Pakistani police, public buses, railways, communication systems, gas pipelines, electricity pylons, check-posts, and civilian offices.
